title: 113_hr627
content:
The Act is titled the "National Park Service 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act". The National Park Service was established in 1916 to administer America's national parks and monuments. Since then, it has grown to include over 395 units with 84 million acres of land across the country. The responsibilities of the National Park Service have expanded to managing historic and scenic trails, administering wild and scenic rivers, and recognizing significant historic resources. The National Park Service, established in 1916, manages national parks and historic landmarks. It provides preservation grants and assists communities with conservation and recreation needs. The core mission is to conserve natural and historic objects for future generations. The 100th anniversary in 2016 celebrated a century of American heritage. In 2016, the National Park Service celebrated its 100th anniversary, highlighting a century of American vision and achievement in preserving the nation's special places. Commemorative coins were issued to bring attention to the National Park System and Congress's legacy in protecting natural and cultural resources. The proceeds from a surcharge on the sale of commemorative coins will assist in financing the needs of the National Park Service's parks and programs, ensuring the preservation of our nation's natural and cultural resources for future generations. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Design of coins. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service, with inscriptions including the face value, year "2016", and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Park Service, National Park Foundation, Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with issuance allowed only from January 1, 2016, to December 31, 2016. The Secretary will sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be discounted, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to the National Park Foundation for projects that preserve and protect resources under the National Park Service's stewardship. The National Park Foundation cannot use funds for land acquisition. The Foundation is subject to audit requirements for the amounts received. There are limitations on surcharges for commemorative coins to not exceed the annual issuance limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for this. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES.

The Secretary will ensure that minting coins will not cost the government and no funds will be disbursed until all costs are recovered. SEC. 9. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. SEC. 9. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. The budgetary effects of this Act must comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The determination will be based on the latest statement submitted by the Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives. Passed the House of Representatives on April 29, 2014.
